title: Lists
description: Lists are continuous, vertical indexes of text or images.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Lists consist of one or more list items, and can contain actions represented by icons and text. List items come in three sizes: one-line, two-line, and three-line.

contentChunks.footer: Two-line items in a list.
contentChunks.altText: Diagram of three list items that each contain a header and supporting text

contentChunks.htmlValue: Resources

TypeLinkStatus
DesignDesign kit (Figma)Available
M2 guideline – ListsAvailable
ImplementationMDC-AndroidNot planned – use recyclerview instead
Jetpack ComposeAvailable
FlutterPlanned
WebPlanned
Takeaways

• Lists should be sorted in logical ways that make content easy to scan, such as alphabetical, numerical, chronological, or by user preference
  • Lists present content in a way that makes it easy to identify a specific item in a collection and act on it
  • Lists should present icons, text, and actions in a consistent format
What's new

• Color: New color mappings and compatibility with dynamic color
  • Layout: Padding and spacing rules are updated to be more consistent
  • Height: The "tallest" element within a list item determines the list item’s height – either 56dp, 72dp, or 88dp
  • Alignment: Elements in a list item are middle-aligned unless it is at or above 88dp (such as when a list item contains three lines of text) at which point everything is top aligned

contentChunks.footer: Lists have new color mapping, height measurements, and alignment
contentChunks.altText: Side by side view of two mobile lists of party planning tasks highlighting subtle style differences from M2 to M3

contentChunks.footer: M2: Non-standard heights and alignments
contentChunks.altText: Examples of 3 types of list in GM2

contentChunks.footer: M3: Standardized heights and alignments
contentChunks.altText: Examples of 3 types of list in M3

Color

Color values are implemented through design tokens. For design, this means working with color values that correspond with tokens. For implementation, a color value will be a token that references a value. Learn more about design tokens.

Contents

Responsive layout

contentChunks.footer: Three list items showing a range of possible configurations.
contentChunks.altText: Diagram of three two-line list items with differences in leading and trailing elements

contentChunks.htmlValue: Usage

Lists are vertically organized groups of text and images. 
 
Optimized for reading comprehension, a list consists of a single continuous column of rows, with each row representing a list item.
 
List items can contain primary and supplemental actions represented by icons and text.

contentChunks.footer: Three list items with an avatar, headline, supporting text, and trailing text.
contentChunks.altText: Three two-line list items

contentChunks.htmlValue: Use lists for communicating or selecting discreet items, such as choosing from a set of colors.

contentChunks.footer: An image and text list made of list items that contain color swatches, color names, and a checkbox action.
contentChunks.altText: List of items with checkboxes. One checkbox is activated, indicating a choice selection.

contentChunks.htmlValue: A list should be easily scannable, and any element of a list can be used to anchor and align list item content. Scannability is improved when elements (such as supporting visual and primary text) are placed in consistent locations across list items.

contentChunks.footer:
1. Sample list
2. Content placement in a row
3. Supporting visuals are aligned for easy scanning
4. Primary text is aligned for easy scanning
contentChunks.altText: Comparison of 4 lists with different elements highlighted

contentChunks.htmlValue:
List items come in three sizes:
 
1. One-line
Single-line list items contain a maximum of one line of text.
 
2. Two-line
Two-line list items contain a maximum of two lines of text.
 
3. Three-line
Three-line list items contain a maximum of three lines of text.

contentChunks.footer: Three sizes of list items.
contentChunks.altText: Comparison of one-line, two-line, and three-line list items

contentChunks.htmlValue: Anatomy

contentChunks.footer:
1. Container
2. Headline
3. Supporting text
4. Trailing supporting text
5. Trailing icon (or icon button)
6. Trailing selection control (checkbox, radio button, handle, etc)
7. Divider (optional)
8. Leading avatar container
9. Leading avatar label text
10. Leading icon
11. Leading media (image or video)
contentChunks.altText: Diagram with 11 elements that can be included in lists

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Container

List containers hold all list items and their elements. List item size is determined by the "tallest" element within the list item. See Specs for layout measurements.

contentChunks.footer: 1. List container
contentChunks.altText: Diagram of list container anatomy

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Headline and supporting text

Headline text often communicates the subject of the list item, such as the name of a photo album or article.

Supporting text includes body content, such as an article summary or a restaurant description.

contentChunks.footer: 1. Headline and supporting text
contentChunks.altText: Diagram of list headline and supporting text anatomy

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Icons

Leading icon
List items can include leading icons.

Trailing icon
List items can include trailing icons.

contentChunks.footer: Example of leading icons in list items
contentChunks.altText: Diagram of list items with leading icons

contentChunks.footer: Example of trailing icons in list items
contentChunks.altText: Diagram of list items with trailing icons

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Leading media or avatar

List items can contain an image, video, or avatar. Anchor visuals to the leading edge of the list to ensure scannability.

Image
List items can include photos, illustrations, and other graphics.

Video
List items can include photos, illustrations, and other graphics, such as weather icons.

contentChunks.footer: Improve scannability by anchoring supporting visuals, such as thumbnails, aligned to the row's leading edge.
contentChunks.altText: Leading thumbnail images improve scannability

contentChunks.footer: Placing supporting visuals in the center of the row can make it difficult to see the relationship between primary content and supporting content.
contentChunks.altText: A list of items with thumbnail images in the center of the each row

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Avatar
List items can include images in a circular crop to represent a person or entity,

contentChunks.altText: A list of names with leading photographs

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Trailing supporting text

Trailing supporting text can be used in addition to inline supporting text to communicate meta-information about the list item, such as price, content count, or other details.

contentChunks.footer: 1. Example of trailing supporting text
contentChunks.altText: Diagram of two-line list item with trailing supporting text

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Selection controls

Controls display information and actions for list items. They can be aligned to the leading or trailing edge of the list item.

Checkbox
Checkboxes can be used to select one or more list items.

Switch
Switches can be used to toggle a control on or off.

Handle
Usually appearing in edit mode, handles allow you to drag list items, moving them to other locations within the list. This reorder icon is the list item's secondary action.

contentChunks.footer: List items with: 1. Checkboxes 2. Switches 3. Handles
contentChunks.altText: Comparison of lists with different trailing elements

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Dividers

Dividers can be used to separate larger list items.

contentChunks.footer: Place a divider between rows with lots of content, such as those with two- or three-line lists.
contentChunks.altText: 2 dividers visually separate 3 list items

contentChunks.footer: Distinguish rows by maintaining sufficient space between list items.
contentChunks.altText: A list of one-line items separated by dividers

contentChunks.htmlValue: Responsive Layout

Spacing

Use spacing to draw attention to the most important aspect of the list item, usually the primary action area or key content.

contentChunks.footer:
The primary action takes up the majority of space.
1. Primary Action area
2. Secondary Action area
contentChunks.altText: Diagram of list item with two action areas

contentChunks.footer:
Clear hierarchy is created by aligning the most distinguishing content on the left, with the least distinguishing on the right.
1. More distinguishing content
2. Less distinguishing content
contentChunks.altText: Diagram of list item with leading avatar and trailing supporting text

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Line length

Avoid excessively long lines of text when expanding containers and text-heavy components  within fluid layouts. This often means changing margins and typography properties as the container scales.

contentChunks.footer: Adjust margins to create a more comfortable line length for reading.
contentChunks.altText: List of items with wrapped supporting text

contentChunks.htmlValue: The ideal line length for text is typically between 40-60 characters, but large screen devices can accommodate up to 120 characters per line. Consider increasing the line height to improve readability if a line of text becomes close to 120 characters in length.

contentChunks.footer: Don’t scale components without adjusting other affected areas of the screen, such as text length. This can result in line lengths that make reading difficult.
contentChunks.altText: List items with with long lines of supporting text

contentChunks.htmlValue: Adapt the width of the list container based on a line’s length, or by switching to a multi-column layout.

contentChunks.footer: A multi-column layout can help break up content when needed.
contentChunks.altText: 2 column list

contentChunks.htmlValue: A three-line list on mobile (1) is displayed as a two-line list on desktop (2).

contentChunks.footer: A multi-column layout can help break up content when needed.
contentChunks.altText: Comparison of app screen with one column list and web screen with two column list

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Component adaptation

Visual presentation is the most common method of adaptation, affecting the scale and placement of content and objects on a screen, as well as their relationships to each other.

For example, a text list on mobile can adjust its margins, vertical spacing, or density to better fit large screens like tablets.

contentChunks.altText: Comparison of app screen list with small leading images and web screen list with large leading images and supportive text

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Component swapping

Given the flexibility needed for lists and cards to support multiple types of content, use caution if swapping between the two on large screens. As screen sizes increase, there are new opportunities for text and image compositions; in large screens you can use more space for images and text.

contentChunks.footer: Information displayed in list items on mobile and in cards on tablet and desktop.
contentChunks.altText: Comparison of app screen list with small leading images and web image list with large images and supportive text. Two different formats and screens support the same information.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Mobile

On smaller screens, lists extend edge-to-edge. Users navigate between full-screen views, as seen in a photo app’s transition from a thumbnail list to full image view.

contentChunks.footer: On small screens, users navigate between full-screen views.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Tablet and desktop

Large screens can display primary and secondary content in the same view, such as a list adjacent to a detail view.

contentChunks.footer: On larger screens, a list/detail view can be more appropriate.
contentChunks.altText: Web screen with 2 columns, one for a list and the other for a detail view

contentChunks.htmlValue: On a larger screen, a list may transform into an image list.

contentChunks.footer:
1. A one-line list on mobile
2. An image list on desktop
contentChunks.altText: Comparison of list with leading images on mobile and image list on desktop

contentChunks.htmlValue: Lists can also show more or less content as they scale up and down in size. For example, a list item can reveal more content when the component expands.

contentChunks.footer: List items on larger screens can display more information as the screen size transitions from small to medium breakpoints.
contentChunks.altText: Comparison of small-screen list without supporting text and large-screen list with supporting text

contentChunks.htmlValue: Behavior

Expanding and collapsing

Tapping a list item expands it vertically across the entire screen using a container transform transition pattern.

contentChunks.footer: To expand a list item, display a parent-child transition.
contentChunks.altText: List item with dropdown menu

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Swiping

Swiping a list item (either left or right) can perform an action.

contentChunks.footer: To archive a list item, swipe it.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Dragging

Items can be dragged to reorder a list.

contentChunks.footer: To reorder a list item, drag it.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Accessibility guidelines coming soon

In progress: complete guidance for accessible interaction, keyboard navigation, labeling, and more. Learn more about accessibility.
